titlepage.titleproper: Inventory of the Charles Brown Papers, 1792-1888.

archdesc.runner: Special Collections, College of William and Mary

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.repository: Special Collections, College of William and Mary
did.abstract: Letters, accounts and legal papers of Dr. Charles Brown.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open to all researchers.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Before publishing quotations or excerpts from any materials, permission must be obtained from the Curator of Manuscripts and Rare Books, and the holder of the copyright, if not Swem Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Charles Brown Papers, Manuscripts and Rare Books Department, Swem Library, College of William and Mary.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Information
bioghist.p: Charles Brown was a physician who resided in Charlottesville, Virginia in the early nineteenth century and who served as sheriff of Albemarle County, Virginia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: Letters, accounts and legal papers of Dr. Charles Brown. Collection includes letters, 1813-1818, concerning patients (including slaves). Includes land signed by Henry Lee and John Tyler, items relating to "Actonplace" [Acton] English estate of William Jennings and plats of land in Albemarle County, Virginia; as well as letters of members of the Brown family.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has been arranged chronologically by date with those items without dates located at the end.

arrangement.head: Organization
arrangement.p: These papers have been organized into four series and two sub-series: 1. Letters,1813-1877 (Folders 1-4); 2. Accounts and Papers of Charles Brown, 1810-1877 (Folders 5-8); 3. Papers relating to Other Members of the Brown family, 1751-1888 (Folder 9); 4. Papers belonging to other persons, 1796-1850(Folder 9).

scopecontent.p: Letters that were sent to or written by Charles Brown.

did.unittitle:
letters relating to the estate of William Jennings of Actonplace England,
1850-1877.

scopecontent.p: Note: On the bottom of the sheet appears a note in the same hand signed James Keaton.

c01.head: Series 2: Accounts and Papers of Charles Brown

did.unittitle:
Accounts and Papers of Charles Brown,
1810-1877.

scopecontent.p: Important accounts and papers that were kept and used by Charles Brown
A deed given by William D. Taylor, United States tax collector for the 18th district of Virginia, to Charles Brown, covering a tract of land in Albemarle County, Virginia.
A warrant issued by John Taylor, Governor of Virginia, granting a tract of land in Albemarle County, Virginia, to Charles Brown.
Papers concerning other lands owned by Charles Brown.
Bonds given by persons appointed by Charles Brown, sheriff of Albemarle County, Virginia, to act as deputies.
Suits against Charles Brown, sheriff of Albemarle County, Virginia.
Suit of G. T. Owens against Charles Brown.
Papers concerning the joint ownership of a horse by Charles Brown and John Fagg.
An article on the habits and economy of the honey bee, by Charles Brown.
Papers relating to a patent for a process of preserving wood discovered by Charles Brown.
Power of attorney given to A. R. Brown and Elvira S. Ayres in the settlement of the Charles Brown estate.

c01.head: Series 3: Papers relating to other members of the Brown Family

did.unittitle:
Papers relating to other members of the Brown family,
1751-1888.

scopecontent.p: Included are letters, accounts, boundary and land identifications, and estate settlement papers.
Papers consisting of invoices, receipts, etc. from members of the Brown family
Papers giving boundaries of land owned by Benjamin and Bezaleel Brown.
A warrant signed by Henry Lee, governor of Virginia, granting to Bazeleel [Bezaleel] Brown a tract of land in Albemarle County, Virginia.
Papers relating to the settlement of the estate of Judith Brown.

c01.head: Series 4: Papers belonging to other persons

scopecontent.p: Papers that were created for or by persons other than the Brown family and found among Charles Brown's papers.
A warrant granting to John Barkley a tract of land in Albemarle County, Virginia.
